question: In this way matters went on for some time, without producing any material [MASK] on the relative situations of the contending powers.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: But what was still more annoying, Brom took all opportunities of turning him into ridicule in presence of his mistress, and had a scoundrel dog whom he taught to whine in the most ludicrous manner, and introduced as a rival of Ichabodâs, to instruct her in psalmody.
next_sentence: On a fine autumnal afternoon, Ichabod, in pensive mood, sat enthroned on the lofty stool from whence he usually watched all the concerns of his little literary realm.

question: It stirred not, but seemed [MASK] up in the gloom, like some gigantic monster ready to spring upon the traveller.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: In the dark shadow of the grove, on the margin of the brook, he beheld something huge, misshapen and towering.
next_sentence: The hair of the affrighted pedagogue rose upon his head with terror.

question: Knots of gazers and gossips were collected in the churchyard, at the bridge, and at the spot where the [MASK] and pumpkin had been found.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The mysterious event caused much speculation at the church on the following Sunday.
next_sentence: The stories of Brouwer, of Bones, and a whole budget of others were called to mind; and when they had diligently considered them all, and compared them with the symptoms of the present case, they shook their heads, and came to the conclusion that Ichabod had been carried off by the Galloping Hessian.

question: Its limbs were gnarled and fantastic, large enough to form trunks for ordinary trees, twisting down almost to the earth, and rising again into the [MASK].
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: In the centre of the road stood an enormous tulip-tree, which towered like a giant above all the other trees of the neighborhood, and formed a kind of landmark.
next_sentence: It was connected with the tragical story of the unfortunate AndrÃ©, who had been taken prisoner hard by; and was universally known by the name of Major AndrÃ©âs tree.

question: The greater part of the time he [MASK] on two or three strings, accompanying every movement of the bow with a motion of the head; bowing almost to the ground, and stamping with his foot whenever a fresh couple were to start.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: His instrument was as old and battered as himself.
next_sentence: Ichabod prided himself upon his dancing as much as upon his vocal powers.

question: His heart began to [MASK] within him; he endeavored to resume his psalm tune, but his parched tongue clove to the roof of his mouth, and he could not utter a stave.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Ichabod pulled up, and fell into a walk, thinking to lag behind,--the other did the same.
next_sentence: There was something in the moody and dogged silence of this pertinacious companion that was mysterious and appalling.

question: The horizon was of a fine golden tint, changing gradually into a pure [MASK] green, and from that into the deep blue of the mid-heaven.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: A few amber clouds floated in the sky, without a breath of air to move them.
next_sentence: A slanting ray lingered on the woody crests of the precipices that overhung some parts of the river, giving greater depth to the dark gray and purple of their rocky sides.

question: The [MASK] was an old gray-headed negro, who had been the itinerant orchestra of the neighborhood for more than half a century.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: His hospitable attentions were brief, but expressive, being confined to a shake of the hand, a slap on the shoulder, a loud laugh, and a pressing invitation to âfall to, and help themselves.â  And now the sound of the music from the common room, or hall, summoned to the dance.
next_sentence: His instrument was as old and battered as himself.

question: His head was small, and flat at top, with huge ears, large green glassy eyes, and a [MASK] snipe nose, so that it looked like a weather-cock perched upon his spindle neck to tell which way the wind blew.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He was tall, but exceedingly lank, with narrow shoulders, long arms and legs, hands that dangled a mile out of his sleeves, feet that might have served for shovels, and his whole frame most loosely hung together.
next_sentence: To see him striding along the profile of a hill on a windy day, with his clothes bagging and fluttering about him, one might have mistaken him for the genius of famine descending upon the earth, or some scarecrow eloped from a cornfield.

question: However wide awake they may have been before they entered that sleepy region, they are sure, in a little time, to inhale the witching influence of the [MASK], and begin to grow imaginative, to dream dreams, and see apparitions.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It is remarkable that the visionary propensity I have mentioned is not confined to the native inhabitants of the valley, but is unconsciously imbibed by every one who resides there for a time.
next_sentence: I mention this peaceful spot with all possible laud, for it is in such little retired Dutch valleys, found here and there embosomed in the great State of New York, that population, manners, and customs remain fixed, while the great torrent of migration and improvement, which is making such incessant changes in other parts of this restless country, sweeps by them unobserved.

question: To see him striding along the profile of a hill on a windy day, with his clothes bagging and [MASK] about him, one might have mistaken him for the genius of famine descending upon the earth, or some scarecrow eloped from a cornfield.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: His head was small, and flat at top, with huge ears, large green glassy eyes, and a long snipe nose, so that it looked like a weather-cock perched upon his spindle neck to tell which way the wind blew.
next_sentence: His schoolhouse was a low building of one large room, rudely constructed of logs; the windows partly glazed, and partly patched with leaves of old copybooks.

question: There was the doughty doughnut, the tender oly koek, and the crisp and crumbling cruller; sweet cakes and short [MASK], ginger cakes and honey cakes, and the whole family of cakes.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Such heaped up platters of cakes of various and almost indescribable kinds, known only to experienced Dutch housewives!
next_sentence: And then there were apple pies, and peach pies, and pumpkin pies; besides slices of ham and smoked beef; and moreover delectable dishes of preserved plums, and peaches, and pears, and quinces; not to mention broiled shad and roasted chickens; together with bowls of milk and cream, all mingled higgledy-piggledy, pretty much as I have enumerated them, with the motherly teapot sending up its clouds of vapor from the midst--Heaven bless the mark!

question: To look upon its grass-grown yard, where the sunbeams [MASK] to sleep so quietly, one would think that there at least the dead might rest in peace.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: A gentle slope descends from it to a silver sheet of water, bordered by high trees, between which, peeps may be caught at the blue hills of the Hudson.
next_sentence: On one side of the church extends a wide woody dell, along which raves a large brook among broken rocks and trunks of fallen trees.

question: The scholars were hurried through their lessons without stopping at trifles; those who were nimble skipped over half with impunity, and those who were tardy had a [MASK] application now and then in the rear, to quicken their speed or help them over a tall word.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: All was now bustle and hubbub in the late quiet schoolroom.
next_sentence: Books were flung aside without being put away on the shelves, inkstands were overturned, benches thrown down, and the whole school was turned loose an hour before the usual time, bursting forth like a legion of young imps, yelping and racketing about the green in joy at their early emancipation.

question: He was foremost at all races and cock fights; and, with the ascendancy which bodily strength [MASK] acquires in rustic life, was the umpire in all disputes, setting his hat on one side, and giving his decisions with an air and tone that admitted of no gainsay or appeal.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He was famed for great knowledge and skill in horsemanship, being as dexterous on horseback as a Tartar.
next_sentence: He was always ready for either a fight or a frolic; but had more mischief than ill-will in his composition; and with all his overbearing roughness, there was a strong dash of waggish good humor at bottom.

question: He was one of your wary men, who never laugh but [MASK] good grounds--when they have reason and law on their side.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: There was, however, one tall, dry-looking old gentleman, with beetling eyebrows, who maintained a grave and rather severe face throughout, now and then folding his arms, inclining his head, and looking down upon the floor, as if turning a doubt over in his mind.
next_sentence: When the mirth of the rest of the company had subsided, and silence was restored, he leaned one arm on the elbow of his chair, and sticking the other akimbo, demanded, with a slight, but exceedingly sage motion of the head, and contraction of the brow, what was the moral of the story, and what it went to prove?

question: How often did he shrink with curdling awe at the sound of his own steps on the frosty crust beneath his feet; and dread to [MASK] over his shoulder, lest he should behold some uncouth being tramping close behind him!
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: How often was he appalled by some shrub covered with snow, which, like a sheeted spectre, beset his very path!
next_sentence: And how often was he thrown into complete dismay by some rushing blast, howling among the trees, in the idea that it was the Galloping Hessian on one of his nightly scourings!

question: It is a great triumph of skill to gain the former, but a still greater proof of generalship to maintain possession of the latter, for man must battle for his fortress at every door and [MASK].
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Some seem to have but one vulnerable point, or door of access; while others have a thousand avenues, and may be captured in a thousand different ways.
next_sentence: He who wins a thousand common hearts is therefore entitled to some renown; but he who keeps undisputed sway over the heart of a coquette is indeed a hero.

question: They are like those little nooks of still water, which border a rapid stream, where we may see the straw and bubble riding quietly at anchor, or slowly revolving in their [MASK] harbor, undisturbed by the rush of the passing current.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: I mention this peaceful spot with all possible laud, for it is in such little retired Dutch valleys, found here and there embosomed in the great State of New York, that population, manners, and customs remain fixed, while the great torrent of migration and improvement, which is making such incessant changes in other parts of this restless country, sweeps by them unobserved.
next_sentence: Though many years have elapsed since I trod the drowsy shades of Sleepy Hollow, yet I question whether I should not still find the same trees and the same families vegetating in its sheltered bosom.

question: Streaming files of wild [MASK] began to make their appearance high in the air; the bark of the squirrel might be heard from the groves of beech and hickory-nuts, and the pensive whistle of the quail at intervals from the neighboring stubble field.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The forests had put on their sober brown and yellow, while some trees of the tenderer kind had been nipped by the frosts into brilliant dyes of orange, purple, and scarlet.
next_sentence: The small birds were taking their farewell banquets.

question: Some of the damsels mounted on pillions behind their favorite swains, and their light-hearted laughter, mingling with the clatter of hoofs, echoed along the [MASK] woodlands, sounding fainter and fainter, until they gradually died away ,--and the late scene of noise and frolic was all silent and deserted.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The old farmers gathered together their families in their wagons, and were heard for some time rattling along the hollow roads, and over the distant hills.
next_sentence: Ichabod only lingered behind, according to the custom of country lovers, to have a tÃªte-Ã -tÃªte with the heiress; fully convinced that he was now on the high road to success.

question: Ichabod endeavored to dodge the [MASK] missile, but too late.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Just then he saw the goblin rising in his stirrups, and in the very act of hurling his head at him.
next_sentence: It encountered his cranium with a tremendous crash,--he was tumbled headlong into the dust, and Gunpowder, the black steed, and the goblin rider, passed by like a whirlwind.

question: The hour was as [MASK] as himself.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It was the very witching time of night that Ichabod, heavy-hearted and crestfallen, pursued his travels homewards, along the sides of the lofty hills which rise above Tarry Town, and which he had traversed so cheerily in the afternoon.
next_sentence: Far below him the Tappan Zee spread its dusky and indistinct waste of waters, with here and there the tall mast of a sloop, riding quietly at anchor under the land.

question: An [MASK] in the trees now cheered him with the hopes that the church bridge was at hand.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow

next_sentence: The wavering reflection of a silver star in the bosom of the brook told him that he was not mistaken.

question: He was, moreover, approaching the very place where many of the scenes of the ghost stories had been [MASK].
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He had never felt so lonely and dismal.

question: He was, in fact, an odd [MASK] of small shrewdness and simple credulity.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He was, moreover, esteemed by the women as a man of great erudition, for he had read several books quite through, and was a perfect master of Cotton Matherâs âHistory of New England Witchcraft,â in which, by the way, he most firmly and potently believed.
next_sentence: His appetite for the marvellous, and his powers of digesting it, were equally extraordinary; and both had been increased by his residence in this spell-bound region.

question: His appearance, therefore, is apt to occasion some little stir at the tea-table of a farmhouse, and the [MASK] of a supernumerary dish of cakes or sweetmeats, or, peradventure, the parade of a silver teapot.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The schoolmaster is generally a man of some importance in the female circle of a rural neighborhood; being considered a kind of idle, gentlemanlike personage, of vastly superior taste and accomplishments to the rough country swains, and, indeed, inferior in learning only to the parson.
next_sentence: Our man of letters, therefore, was peculiarly happy in the smiles of all the country damsels.

question: Whatever money the schoolmaster possessed, and he had received his quarterâs pay but a day or two before, he must have had about his [MASK] at the time of his disappearance.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow

title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: these women!
next_sentence: Was her encouragement of the poor pedagogue all a mere sham to secure her conquest of his rival?

question: Not far from this village, perhaps about two [MASK], there is a little valley or rather lap of land among high hills, which is one of the quietest places in the whole world.

title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Be that as it may, I do not vouch for the fact, but merely advert to it, for the sake of being precise and authentic.
next_sentence: A small brook glides through it, with just murmur enough to lull one to repose; and the occasional whistle of a quail or tapping of a woodpecker is almost the only sound that ever breaks in upon the uniform tranquillity.

question: To me they have always been matters of [MASK] and admiration.

prev_sentence: I profess not to know how womenâs hearts are wooed and won.

title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It stirred not, but seemed gathered up in the gloom, like some gigantic monster ready to spring upon the traveller.

question: Certain it is, the place still continues under the sway of some witching power, that holds a spell over the minds of the good people, causing them to walk in a [MASK] reverie.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Some say that the place was bewitched by a High German doctor, during the early days of the settlement; others, that an old Indian chief, the prophet or wizard of his tribe, held his powwows there before the country was discovered by Master Hendrick Hudson.
next_sentence: They are given to all kinds of marvellous beliefs, are subject to trances and visions, and frequently see strange sights, and hear music and voices in the air.

question: This has ever since been considered a haunted stream, and fearful are the [MASK] of the schoolboy who has to pass it alone after dark.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It was at this identical spot that the unfortunate AndrÃ© was captured, and under the covert of those chestnuts and vines were the sturdy yeomen concealed who surprised him.
next_sentence: As he approached the stream, his heart began to thump; he summoned up, however, all his resolution, gave his horse half a score of kicks in the ribs, and attempted to dash briskly across the bridge; but instead of starting forward, the perverse old animal made a lateral movement, and ran broadside against the fence.

next_sentence: The story-teller, who was just putting a glass of wine to his lips, as a refreshment after his toils, paused for a moment, looked at his inquirer with an air of infinite deference, and, lowering the glass slowly to the table, observed that the story was intended most logically to prove--  âThat there is no situation in life but has its advantages and pleasures--provided we will but take a joke as we find it:  âThat, therefore, he that runs races with goblin troopers is likely to have rough riding of it.

title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow

next_sentence: The scholars were hurried through their lessons without stopping at trifles; those who were nimble skipped over half with impunity, and those who were tardy had a smart application now and then in the rear, to quicken their speed or help them over a tall word.

question: He appeared to be a horseman of large dimensions, and [MASK] on a black horse of powerful frame.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Though the night was dark and dismal, yet the form of the unknown might now in some degree be ascertained.
next_sentence: He made no offer of molestation or sociability, but kept aloof on one side of the road, jogging along on the blind side of old Gunpowder, who had now got over his fright and waywardness.

question: Ichabod, therefore, [MASK] his advances in a quiet and gently insinuating manner.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: To have taken the field openly against his rival would have been madness; for he was not a man to be thwarted in his amours, any more than that stormy lover, Achilles.
next_sentence: Under cover of his character of singing-master, he made frequent visits at the farmhouse; not that he had anything to apprehend from the meddlesome interference of parents, which is so often a stumbling-block in the path of lovers.

question: He was a kind and thankful [MASK], whose heart dilated in proportion as his skin was filled with good cheer, and whose spirits rose with eating, as some menâs do with drink.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Happily, Ichabod Crane was not in so great a hurry as his historian, but did ample justice to every dainty.
next_sentence: He could not help, too, rolling his large eyes round him as he ate, and chuckling with the possibility that he might one day be lord of all this scene of almost unimaginable luxury and splendor.

question: The forests had put on their sober brown and yellow, while some trees of the tenderer kind had been [MASK] by the frosts into brilliant dyes of orange, purple, and scarlet.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It was, as I have said, a fine autumnal day; the sky was clear and serene, and nature wore that rich and golden livery which we always associate with the idea of abundance.
next_sentence: Streaming files of wild ducks began to make their appearance high in the air; the bark of the squirrel might be heard from the groves of beech and hickory-nuts, and the pensive whistle of the quail at intervals from the neighboring stubble field.

question: But if there was a pleasure in all this, while snugly cuddling in the chimney corner of a chamber that was all of a ruddy glow from the crackling wood fire, and where, of course, no spectre dared to show its face, it was dearly purchased by the terrors of his [MASK] walk homewards.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He would delight them equally by his anecdotes of witchcraft, and of the direful omens and portentous sights and sounds in the air, which prevailed in the earlier times of Connecticut; and would frighten them woefully with speculations upon comets and shooting stars; and with the alarming fact that the world did absolutely turn round, and that they were half the time topsy-turvy!
next_sentence: What fearful shapes and shadows beset his path, amidst the dim and ghastly glare of a snowy night!

question: The pedagogueâs mouth watered as he looked upon this sumptuous [MASK] of luxurious winter fare.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Before the barn door strutted the gallant cock, that pattern of a husband, a warrior and a fine gentleman, clapping his burnished wings and crowing in the pride and gladness of his heart,--sometimes tearing up the earth with his feet, and then generously calling his ever-hungry family of wives and children to enjoy the rich morsel which he had discovered.
next_sentence: In his devouring mindâs eye, he pictured to himself every roasting-pig running about with a pudding in his belly, and an apple in his mouth; the pigeons were snugly put to bed in a comfortable pie, and tucked in with a coverlet of crust; the geese were swimming in their own gravy; and the ducks pairing cosily in dishes, like snug married couples, with a decent competency of onion sauce.

question: In [MASK] to his other vocations, he was the singing-master of the neighborhood, and picked up many bright shillings by instructing the young folks in psalmody.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He found favor in the eyes of the mothers by petting the children, particularly the youngest; and like the lion bold, which whilom so magnanimously the lamb did hold, he would sit with a child on one knee, and rock a cradle with his foot for whole hours together.
next_sentence: It was a matter of no little vanity to him on Sundays, to take his station in front of the church gallery, with a band of chosen singers; where, in his own mind, he completely carried away the palm from the parson.

question: With these he lived successively a week at a time, thus going the rounds of the neighborhood, with all his [MASK] effects tied up in a cotton handkerchief.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The revenue arising from his school was small, and would have been scarcely sufficient to furnish him with daily bread, for he was a huge feeder, and, though lank, had the dilating powers of an anaconda; but to help out his maintenance, he was, according to country custom in those parts, boarded and lodged at the houses of the farmers whose children he instructed.
next_sentence: That all this might not be too onerous on the purses of his rustic patrons, who are apt to consider the costs of schooling a grievous burden, and schoolmasters as mere drones, he had various ways of rendering himself both useful and agreeable.

question: She was withal a little of a coquette, as might be perceived [MASK] in her dress, which was a mixture of ancient and modern fashions, as most suited to set off her charms.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: She was a blooming lass of fresh eighteen; plump as a partridge; ripe and melting and rosy-cheeked as one of her fatherâs peaches, and universally famed, not merely for her beauty, but her vast expectations.
next_sentence: She wore the ornaments of pure yellow gold, which her great-great-grandmother had brought over from Saardam; the tempting stomacher of the olden time, and withal a provokingly short petticoat, to display the prettiest foot and ankle in the country round.

question: How often was he appalled by some shrub covered with [MASK], which, like a sheeted spectre, beset his very path!
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: With what wistful look did he eye every trembling ray of light streaming across the waste fields from some distant window!
next_sentence: How often did he shrink with curdling awe at the sound of his own steps on the frosty crust beneath his feet; and dread to look over his shoulder, lest he should behold some uncouth being tramping close behind him!

question: The schoolhouse stood in a rather lonely but pleasant situation, just at the foot of a woody hill, with a brook running close by, and a [MASK] birch-tree growing at one end of it.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It was most ingeniously secured at vacant hours, by a withe twisted in the handle of the door, and stakes set against the window shutters; so that though a thief might get in with perfect ease, he would find some embarrassment in getting out,--an idea most probably borrowed by the architect, Yost Van Houten, from the mystery of an eelpot.
next_sentence: From hence the low murmur of his pupilsâ voices, conning over their lessons, might be heard in a drowsy summerâs day, like the hum of a beehive; interrupted now and then by the authoritative voice of the master, in the tone of menace or command, or, peradventure, by the appalling sound of the birch, as he urged some tardy loiterer along the flowery path of knowledge.

question: The animal he bestrode was a broken-down plow-horse, that had outlived almost [MASK] but its viciousness.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: But it is meet I should, in the true spirit of romantic story, give some account of the looks and equipments of my hero and his steed.
next_sentence: He was gaunt and shagged, with a ewe neck, and a head like a hammer; his rusty mane and tail were tangled and knotted with burs; one eye had lost its pupil, and was glaring and spectral, but the other had the gleam of a genuine devil in it.

question: The whole neighborhood abounds with local tales, haunted spots, and twilight superstitions; stars shoot and meteors glare oftener across the valley than in any other part of the country, and the nightmare, with her whole ninefold, seems to make it the [MASK] scene of her gambols.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: They are given to all kinds of marvellous beliefs, are subject to trances and visions, and frequently see strange sights, and hear music and voices in the air.
next_sentence: The dominant spirit, however, that haunts this enchanted region, and seems to be commander-in-chief of all the powers of the air, is the apparition of a figure on horseback, without a head.

question: When his story was concluded, there was much laughter and approbation, [MASK] from two or three deputy aldermen, who had been asleep the greater part of the time.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The narrator was a pleasant, shabby, gentlemanly old fellow, in pepper-and-salt clothes, with a sadly humourous face, and one whom I strongly suspected of being poor--he made such efforts to be entertaining.
next_sentence: There was, however, one tall, dry-looking old gentleman, with beetling eyebrows, who maintained a grave and rather severe face throughout, now and then folding his arms, inclining his head, and looking down upon the floor, as if turning a doubt over in his mind.

question: Their brisk, withered [MASK] dames, in close-crimped caps, long-waisted short gowns, homespun petticoats, with scissors and pincushions, and gay calico pockets hanging on the outside.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Old farmers, a spare leathern-faced race, in homespun coats and breeches, blue stockings, huge shoes, and magnificent pewter buckles.
next_sentence: Buxom lasses, almost as antiquated as their mothers, excepting where a straw hat, a fine ribbon, or perhaps a white frock, gave symptoms of city innovation.

question: The dominant spirit, however, that haunts this enchanted region, and seems to be commander-in-chief of all the powers of the air, is the apparition of a [MASK] on horseback, without a head.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The whole neighborhood abounds with local tales, haunted spots, and twilight superstitions; stars shoot and meteors glare oftener across the valley than in any other part of the country, and the nightmare, with her whole ninefold, seems to make it the favorite scene of her gambols.
next_sentence: It is said by some to be the ghost of a Hessian trooper, whose head had been carried away by a cannon-ball, in some nameless battle during the Revolutionary War, and who is ever and anon seen by the country folk hurrying along in the gloom of night, as if on the wings of the wind.

question: Besides, there is no encouragement for ghosts in most of our villages, for they have scarcely had time to finish their first nap and turn themselves in their graves, before their surviving friends have travelled away from the neighborhood; so that when they turn out at night to [MASK] their rounds, they have no acquaintance left to call upon.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Local tales and superstitions thrive best in these sheltered, long-settled retreats; but are trampled under foot by the shifting throng that forms the population of most of our country places.
next_sentence: This is perhaps the reason why we so seldom hear of ghosts except in our long-established Dutch communities.

question: No signs of life occurred near him, but occasionally the melancholy chirp of a [MASK], or perhaps the guttural twang of a bullfrog from a neighboring marsh, as if sleeping uncomfortably and turning suddenly in his bed.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Now and then, too, the long-drawn crowing of a cock, accidentally awakened, would sound far, far off, from some farmhouse away among the hills--but it was like a dreaming sound in his ear.
next_sentence: All the stories of ghosts and goblins that he had heard in the afternoon now came crowding upon his recollection.

question: Without looking to the right or left to notice the scene of rural wealth, on which he had so often gloated, he went straight to the stable, and with several hearty cuffs and kicks roused his steed most uncourteously from the comfortable quarters in which he was soundly sleeping, dreaming of mountains of corn and oats, and whole valleys of timothy and [MASK].
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Let it suffice to say, Ichabod stole forth with the air of one who had been sacking a henroost, rather than a fair ladyâs heart.
next_sentence: It was the very witching time of night that Ichabod, heavy-hearted and crestfallen, pursued his travels homewards, along the sides of the lofty hills which rise above Tarry Town, and which he had traversed so cheerily in the afternoon.

question: In the centre of the road stood an enormous tulip-tree, which towered like a giant above all the other trees of the neighborhood, and [MASK] a kind of landmark.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He was, moreover, approaching the very place where many of the scenes of the ghost stories had been laid.
next_sentence: Its limbs were gnarled and fantastic, large enough to form trunks for ordinary trees, twisting down almost to the earth, and rising again into the air.

question: The neighborhood is rich in legendary [MASK] of the kind.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: But all these were nothing to the tales of ghosts and apparitions that succeeded.
next_sentence: Local tales and superstitions thrive best in these sheltered, long-settled retreats; but are trampled under foot by the shifting throng that forms the population of most of our country places.

question: Over a deep black part of the stream, not far from the church, was formerly thrown a wooden bridge; the road that led to it, and the bridge itself, were thickly shaded by overhanging trees, which cast a gloom about it, even in the daytime; but occasioned a fearful [MASK] at night.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: On one side of the church extends a wide woody dell, along which raves a large brook among broken rocks and trunks of fallen trees.
next_sentence: Such was one of the favorite haunts of the Headless Horseman, and the place where he was most frequently encountered.

question: Now and then, too, the long-drawn crowing of a cock, accidentally awakened, would sound far, far off, from some farmhouse away among the hills--but it was like a dreaming [MASK] in his ear.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: In the dead hush of midnight, he could even hear the barking of the watchdog from the opposite shore of the Hudson; but it was so vague and faint as only to give an idea of his distance from this faithful companion of man.
next_sentence: No signs of life occurred near him, but occasionally the melancholy chirp of a cricket, or perhaps the guttural twang of a bullfrog from a neighboring marsh, as if sleeping uncomfortably and turning suddenly in his bed.

question: He had three or four boon companions, who regarded him as their model, and at the head of whom he scoured the country, attending every scene of feud or [MASK] for miles round.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He was always ready for either a fight or a frolic; but had more mischief than ill-will in his composition; and with all his overbearing roughness, there was a strong dash of waggish good humor at bottom.
next_sentence: In cold weather he was distinguished by a fur cap, surmounted with a flaunting foxâs tail; and when the folks at a country gathering descried this well-known crest at a distance, whisking about among a squad of hard riders, they always stood by for a squall.

question: The fireflies, too, which sparkled most vividly in the [MASK] places, now and then startled him, as one of uncommon brightness would stream across his path; and if, by chance, a huge blockhead of a beetle came winging his blundering flight against him, the poor varlet was ready to give up the ghost, with the idea that he was struck with a witchâs token.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Then, as he wended his way by swamp and stream and awful woodland, to the farmhouse where he happened to be quartered, every sound of nature, at that witching hour, fluttered his excited imagination,--the moan of the whip-poor-will from the hillside, the boding cry of the tree toad, that harbinger of storm, the dreary hooting of the screech owl, or the sudden rustling in the thicket of birds frightened from their roost.
next_sentence: His only resource on such occasions, either to drown thought or drive away evil spirits, was to sing psalm tunes and the good people of Sleepy Hollow, as they sat by their doors of an evening, were often filled with awe at hearing his nasal melody, âin linked sweetness long drawn out,â  floating from the distant hill, or along the dusky road.

question: As he approached a little nearer, he thought he saw something white, hanging in the midst of the tree: he paused and ceased whistling but, on looking more narrowly, perceived that it was a [MASK] where the tree had been scathed by lightning, and the white wood laid bare.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: As Ichabod approached this fearful tree, he began to whistle; he thought his whistle was answered; it was but a blast sweeping sharply through the dry branches.
next_sentence: Suddenly he heard a groan--his teeth chattered, and his knees smote against the saddle: it was but the rubbing of one huge bough upon another, as they were swayed about by the breeze.

question: Local tales and superstitions thrive best in these sheltered, long-settled retreats; but are trampled under foot by the shifting throng that [MASK] the population of most of our country places.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The neighborhood is rich in legendary treasures of the kind.
next_sentence: Besides, there is no encouragement for ghosts in most of our villages, for they have scarcely had time to finish their first nap and turn themselves in their graves, before their surviving friends have travelled away from the neighborhood; so that when they turn out at night to walk their rounds, they have no acquaintance left to call upon.

question: They are given to all kinds of marvellous beliefs, are subject to trances and visions, and frequently see strange sights, and hear music and voices in the [MASK].
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Certain it is, the place still continues under the sway of some witching power, that holds a spell over the minds of the good people, causing them to walk in a continual reverie.
next_sentence: The whole neighborhood abounds with local tales, haunted spots, and twilight superstitions; stars shoot and meteors glare oftener across the valley than in any other part of the country, and the nightmare, with her whole ninefold, seems to make it the favorite scene of her gambols.

question: Before the barn door strutted the gallant cock, that pattern of a husband, a warrior and a fine gentleman, clapping his burnished wings and crowing in the pride and gladness of his heart ,--sometimes tearing up the earth with his feet, and then generously calling his ever-hungry family of wives and [MASK] to enjoy the rich morsel which he had discovered.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: A stately squadron of snowy geese were riding in an adjoining pond, convoying whole fleets of ducks; regiments of turkeys were gobbling through the farmyard, and Guinea fowls fretting about it, like ill-tempered housewives, with their peevish, discontented cry.
next_sentence: The pedagogueâs mouth watered as he looked upon this sumptuous promise of luxurious winter fare.

question: As yet the panic of the steed had given his unskilful rider an apparent advantage in the chase, but just as he had got half way through the hollow, the girths of the saddle gave way, and he [MASK] it slipping from under him.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: This road leads through a sandy hollow shaded by trees for about a quarter of a mile, where it crosses the bridge famous in goblin story; and just beyond swells the green knoll on which stands the whitewashed church.
next_sentence: He seized it by the pommel, and endeavored to hold it firm, but in vain; and had just time to save himself by clasping old Gunpowder round the neck, when the saddle fell to the earth, and he heard it trampled under foot by his pursuer.

question: He saw the walls of the church dimly [MASK] under the trees beyond.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The wavering reflection of a silver star in the bosom of the brook told him that he was not mistaken.
next_sentence: He recollected the place where Brom Bonesâs ghostly competitor had disappeared.

question: Ichabod pulled up, and [MASK] into a walk, thinking to lag behind ,--the other did the same.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The stranger, however, quickened his horse to an equal pace.
next_sentence: His heart began to sink within him; he endeavored to resume his psalm tune, but his parched tongue clove to the roof of his mouth, and he could not utter a stave.

question: With what wistful look did he eye every trembling ray of light streaming across the waste fields from some [MASK] window!
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: What fearful shapes and shadows beset his path, amidst the dim and ghastly glare of a snowy night!
next_sentence: How often was he appalled by some shrub covered with snow, which, like a sheeted spectre, beset his very path!

question: He could not help, too, rolling his large eyes round him as he ate, and chuckling with the possibility that he might one day be [MASK] of all this scene of almost unimaginable luxury and splendor.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He was a kind and thankful creature, whose heart dilated in proportion as his skin was filled with good cheer, and whose spirits rose with eating, as some menâs do with drink.
next_sentence: Then, he thought, how soon heâd turn his back upon the old schoolhouse; snap his fingers in the face of Hans Van Ripper, and every other niggardly patron, and kick any itinerant pedagogue out of doors that should dare to call him comrade!

question: To turn and fly was now too late; and besides, what chance was there of escaping ghost or goblin, if such it was, which could ride upon the wings of the [MASK]?
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: What was to be done?
next_sentence: Summoning up, therefore, a show of courage, he demanded in stammering accents, âWho are you?â  He received no reply.

question: The schoolmaster is [MASK] a man of some importance in the female circle of a rural neighborhood; being considered a kind of idle, gentlemanlike personage, of vastly superior taste and accomplishments to the rough country swains, and, indeed, inferior in learning only to the parson.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Thus, by divers little makeshifts, in that ingenious way which is commonly denominated âby hook and by crook,â the worthy pedagogue got on tolerably enough, and was thought, by all who understood nothing of the labor of headwork, to have a wonderfully easy life of it.
next_sentence: His appearance, therefore, is apt to occasion some little stir at the tea-table of a farmhouse, and the addition of a supernumerary dish of cakes or sweetmeats, or, peradventure, the parade of a silver teapot.

question: On that side of the road where the brook entered the wood, a group of oaks and [MASK], matted thick with wild grape-vines, threw a cavernous gloom over it.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: A few rough logs, laid side by side, served for a bridge over this stream.
next_sentence: To pass this bridge was the severest trial.

question: Benches were built along the sides for summer use; and a great spinning-wheel at one end, and a churn at the other, showed the various [MASK] to which this important porch might be devoted.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Under this were hung flails, harness, various utensils of husbandry, and nets for fishing in the neighboring river.
next_sentence: From this piazza the wondering Ichabod entered the hall, which formed the centre of the mansion, and the place of usual residence.

question: He passed the tree in [MASK], but new perils lay before him.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Suddenly he heard a groan--his teeth chattered, and his knees smote against the saddle: it was but the rubbing of one huge bough upon another, as they were swayed about by the breeze.
next_sentence: About two hundred yards from the tree, a small brook crossed the road, and ran into a marshy and thickly-wooded glen, known by the name of Wileyâs Swamp.

question: From his half-itinerant life, also, he was a kind of travelling gazette, carrying the whole budget of local gossip from [MASK] to house, so that his appearance was always greeted with satisfaction.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: How he would figure among them in the churchyard, between services on Sundays; gathering grapes for them from the wild vines that overran the surrounding trees; reciting for their amusement all the epitaphs on the tombstones; or sauntering, with a whole bevy of them, along the banks of the adjacent millpond; while the more bashful country bumpkins hung sheepishly back, envying his superior elegance and address.
next_sentence: He was, moreover, esteemed by the women as a man of great erudition, for he had read several books quite through, and was a perfect master of Cotton Matherâs âHistory of New England Witchcraft,â in which, by the way, he most firmly and potently believed.

question: Indeed, it [MASK] him to keep on good terms with his pupils.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: All this he called âdoing his duty by their parents;â and he never inflicted a chastisement without following it by the assurance, so consolatory to the smarting urchin, that âhe would remember it and thank him for it the longest day he had to live.â  When school hours were over, he was even the companion and playmate of the larger boys; and on holiday afternoons would convoy some of the smaller ones home, who happened to have pretty sisters, or good housewives for mothers, noted for the comforts of the cupboard.
next_sentence: The revenue arising from his school was small, and would have been scarcely sufficient to furnish him with daily bread, for he was a huge feeder, and, though lank, had the dilating powers of an anaconda; but to help out his maintenance, he was, according to country custom in those parts, boarded and lodged at the houses of the farmers whose children he instructed.

question: They consisted of two shirts and a half; two stocks for the neck; a [MASK] or two of worsted stockings; an old pair of corduroy small-clothes; a rusty razor; a book of psalm tunes full of dogâs-ears; and a broken pitch-pipe.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Hans Van Ripper as executor of his estate, examined the bundle which contained all his worldly effects.
next_sentence: As to the books and furniture of the schoolhouse, they belonged to the community, excepting Cotton Matherâs âHistory of Witchcraft,â a âNew England Almanac,â and a book of dreams and fortune-telling; in which last was a sheet of foolscap much scribbled and blotted in several fruitless attempts to make a copy of verses in honor of the heiress of Van Tassel.

question: The sun gradually wheeled his broad [MASK] down in the west.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Thus feeding his mind with many sweet thoughts and âsugared suppositions,â he journeyed along the sides of a range of hills which look out upon some of the goodliest scenes of the mighty Hudson.
next_sentence: The wide bosom of the Tappan Zee lay motionless and glassy, excepting that here and there a gentle undulation waved and prolonged the blue shadow of the distant mountain.

question: Thus, by divers little makeshifts, in that ingenious way which is [MASK] denominated âby hook and by crook, â the worthy pedagogue got on tolerably enough, and was thought, by all who understood nothing of the labor of headwork, to have a wonderfully easy life of it.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Certain it is, his voice resounded far above all the rest of the congregation; and there are peculiar quavers still to be heard in that church, and which may even be heard half a mile off, quite to the opposite side of the millpond, on a still Sunday morning, which are said to be legitimately descended from the nose of Ichabod Crane.
next_sentence: The schoolmaster is generally a man of some importance in the female circle of a rural neighborhood; being considered a kind of idle, gentlemanlike personage, of vastly superior taste and accomplishments to the rough country swains, and, indeed, inferior in learning only to the parson.

question: Just then he saw the goblin rising in his stirrups, and in the very act of hurling his [MASK] at him.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Another convulsive kick in the ribs, and old Gunpowder sprang upon the bridge; he thundered over the resounding planks; he gained the opposite side; and now Ichabod cast a look behind to see if his pursuer should vanish, according to rule, in a flash of fire and brimstone.
next_sentence: Ichabod endeavored to dodge the horrible missile, but too late.

question: He laid aside, too, all the dominant dignity and absolute [MASK] with which he lorded it in his little empire, the school, and became wonderfully gentle and ingratiating.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He assisted the farmers occasionally in the lighter labors of their farms, helped to make hay, mended the fences, took the horses to water, drove the cows from pasture, and cut wood for the winter fire.
next_sentence: He found favor in the eyes of the mothers by petting the children, particularly the youngest; and like the lion bold, which whilom so magnanimously the lamb did hold, he would sit with a child on one knee, and rock a cradle with his foot for whole hours together.

question: Ichabod was a suitable [MASK] for such a steed.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He had, in fact, been a favorite steed of his masterâs, the choleric Van Ripper, who was a furious rider, and had infused, very probably, some of his own spirit into the animal; for, old and broken-down as he looked, there was more of the lurking devil in him than in any young filly in the country.
next_sentence: He rode with short stirrups, which brought his knees nearly up to the pommel of the saddle; his sharp elbows stuck out like grasshoppersâ; he carried his whip perpendicularly in his hand, like a sceptre, and as his horse jogged on, the motion of his arms was not unlike the flapping of a pair of wings.

question: The common people regarded it with a mixture of respect and superstition, partly out of sympathy for the fate of its ill-starred namesake, and partly from the tales of strange sights, and [MASK] lamentations, told concerning it.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It was connected with the tragical story of the unfortunate AndrÃ©, who had been taken prisoner hard by; and was universally known by the name of Major AndrÃ©âs tree.
next_sentence: As Ichabod approached this fearful tree, he began to whistle; he thought his whistle was answered; it was but a blast sweeping sharply through the dry branches.

question: At [MASK] he observed that all this was very well, but still he thought the story a little on the extravagant--there were one or two points on which he had his doubts.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: âErgo, for a country schoolmaster to be refused the hand of a Dutch heiress is a certain step to high preferment in the state.â  The cautious old gentleman knit his brows tenfold closer after this explanation, being sorely puzzled by the ratiocination of the syllogism, while, methought, the one in pepper-and-salt eyed him with something of a triumphant leer.
next_sentence: âFaith, sir,â replied the story-teller, âas to that matter, I donât believe one-half of it myself.â  D. K.  THE END.

question: The brook was searched, but the body of the schoolmaster was not to be [MASK].
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: In one part of the road leading to the church was found the saddle trampled in the dirt; the tracks of horsesâ hoofs deeply dented in the road, and evidently at furious speed, were traced to the bridge, beyond which, on the bank of a broad part of the brook, where the water ran deep and black, was found the hat of the unfortunate Ichabod, and close beside it a shattered pumpkin.
next_sentence: Hans Van Ripper as executor of his estate, examined the bundle which contained all his worldly effects.

question: They harried his hitherto [MASK] domains; smoked out his singing school by stopping up the chimney; broke into the schoolhouse at night, in spite of its formidable fastenings of withe and window stakes, and turned everything topsy-turvy, so that the poor schoolmaster began to think all the witches in the country held their meetings there.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Ichabod became the object of whimsical persecution to Bones and his gang of rough riders.
next_sentence: But what was still more annoying, Brom took all opportunities of turning him into ridicule in presence of his mistress, and had a scoundrel dog whom he taught to whine in the most ludicrous manner, and introduced as a rival of Ichabodâs, to instruct her in psalmody.

question: Ichabodâs flimsy [MASK] fluttered in the air, as he stretched his long lank body away over his horseâs head, in the eagerness of his flight.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Away, then, they dashed through thick and thin; stones flying and sparks flashing at every bound.
next_sentence: They had now reached the road which turns off to Sleepy Hollow; but Gunpowder, who seemed possessed with a demon, instead of keeping up it, made an opposite turn, and plunged headlong downhill to the left.

question: There was something in the moody and dogged silence of this pertinacious [MASK] that was mysterious and appalling.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: His heart began to sink within him; he endeavored to resume his psalm tune, but his parched tongue clove to the roof of his mouth, and he could not utter a stave.
next_sentence: It was soon fearfully accounted for.

question: He was tall, but exceedingly lank, with narrow shoulders, long arms and legs, hands that [MASK] a mile out of his sleeves, feet that might have served for shovels, and his whole frame most loosely hung together.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The cognomen of Crane was not inapplicable to his person.
next_sentence: His head was small, and flat at top, with huge ears, large green glassy eyes, and a long snipe nose, so that it looked like a weather-cock perched upon his spindle neck to tell which way the wind blew.

question: To [MASK] this bridge was the severest trial.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: On that side of the road where the brook entered the wood, a group of oaks and chestnuts, matted thick with wild grape-vines, threw a cavernous gloom over it.
next_sentence: It was at this identical spot that the unfortunate AndrÃ© was captured, and under the covert of those chestnuts and vines were the sturdy yeomen concealed who surprised him.

question: He was, in fact, noted for preferring vicious animals, given to all kinds of tricks which kept the rider in constant risk of his [MASK], for he held a tractable, well-broken horse as unworthy of a lad of spirit.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: Brom Bones, however, was the hero of the scene, having come to the gathering on his favorite steed Daredevil, a creature, like himself, full of mettle and mischief, and which no one but himself could manage.
next_sentence: Fain would I pause to dwell upon the world of charms that burst upon the enraptured gaze of my hero, as he entered the state parlor of Van Tasselâs mansion.

question: His [MASK] for the marvellous, and his powers of digesting it, were equally extraordinary; and both had been increased by his residence in this spell-bound region.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: He was, in fact, an odd mixture of small shrewdness and simple credulity.
next_sentence: No tale was too gross or monstrous for his capacious swallow.

question: Old farmers, a spare leathern-faced race, in [MASK] coats and breeches, blue stockings, huge shoes, and magnificent pewter buckles.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It was toward evening that Ichabod arrived at the castle of the Heer Van Tassel, which he found thronged with the pride and flower of the adjacent country.
next_sentence: Their brisk, withered little dames, in close-crimped caps, long-waisted short gowns, homespun petticoats, with scissors and pincushions, and gay calico pockets hanging on the outside.

question: His haunts are not confined to the valley, but extend at times to the adjacent roads, and especially to the vicinity of a [MASK] at no great distance.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It is said by some to be the ghost of a Hessian trooper, whose head had been carried away by a cannon-ball, in some nameless battle during the Revolutionary War, and who is ever and anon seen by the country folk hurrying along in the gloom of night, as if on the wings of the wind.
next_sentence: Indeed, certain of the most authentic historians of those parts, who have been careful in collecting and collating the floating facts concerning this spectre, allege that the body of the trooper having been buried in the churchyard, the ghost rides forth to the scene of battle in nightly quest of his head, and that the rushing speed with which he sometimes passes along the Hollow, like a midnight blast, is owing to his being belated, and in a hurry to get back to the churchyard before daybreak.

question: No tale was too gross or monstrous for his [MASK] swallow.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: His appetite for the marvellous, and his powers of digesting it, were equally extraordinary; and both had been increased by his residence in this spell-bound region.
next_sentence: It was often his delight, after his school was dismissed in the afternoon, to stretch himself on the rich bed of clover bordering the little brook that whimpered by his schoolhouse, and there con over old Matherâs direful tales, until the gathering dusk of evening made the printed page a mere mist before his eyes.

question: There was a contagion in the very air that blew from that haunted region; it breathed forth an atmosphere of dreams and [MASK] infecting all the land.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: The immediate cause, however, of the prevalence of supernatural stories in these parts, was doubtless owing to the vicinity of Sleepy Hollow.
next_sentence: Several of the Sleepy Hollow people were present at Van Tasselâs, and, as usual, were doling out their wild and wonderful legends.

question: The next morning the [MASK] horse was found without his saddle, and with the bridle under his feet, soberly cropping the grass at his masterâs gate.
source_info: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Crayon, Geoffrey
title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
prev_sentence: It encountered his cranium with a tremendous crash,--he was tumbled headlong into the dust, and Gunpowder, the black steed, and the goblin rider, passed by like a whirlwind.
next_sentence: Ichabod did not make his appearance at breakfast; dinner-hour came, but no Ichabod.
